study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of various treatments, including Low-Level Laser Therapy, for lateral elbow pain (tennis elbow).
results_summary: The study included Low-Level Laser Therapy among interventions reviewed but did not provide specific outcome details for it in the abstract. The overall review found mixed evidence for various treatments, with GRADE evaluations indicating varying quality of evidence.
population_specificity: Individuals with lateral elbow pain (tennis elbow).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on exercise performance, oxidative stress, and muscle status in humans.
results_summary: LLLT significantly improved exercise performance (VO₂ max and time to exhaustion), reduced post-exercise oxidative damage to lipids and proteins, and decreased muscle damage markers (CK and LDH), but did not affect aerobic or anaerobic thresholds or CAT activity.
population_specificity: 22 untrained male volunteers
effective_dosage: 810 nm, 200 mW, 30 J per site, 30 s irradiation per site, applied to 12 sites per lower limb (total 360 J per limb)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential diagnostic and therapeutic utility of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in traumatic brain injury (TBI), focusing on its mechanisms and clinical translation.
results_summary: The study suggests LLLT may modulate acute glutamatergic hyperexcitability and subacute GABAergic effects in TBI, potentially aiding cortical reorganization and functional restoration in chronic stages. However, comprehensive safety trials and well-designed clinical studies are needed to confirm its efficacy.
population_specificity: Individuals with traumatic brain injury (TBI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in preventing and treating oral mucositis (OM) induced by cancer therapy.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced the risk of developing OM and decreased the severity and duration of symptoms compared to placebo. The preventive effect was stronger with adequate doses above 1 J.
population_specificity: Head and neck cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy or radiation therapy.
effective_dosage: Adequate doses above 1 J (specific frequency not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) improves dental implant stability using resonance frequency analysis (RFA).
results_summary: The study found no evidence that LLLT improved implant stability, with both irradiated and control groups showing similar stability patterns over time, including a significant drop in stability from the 10th day to the 6th week followed by a gradual increase.
population_specificity: Eight patients with 30 implants bilaterally placed in the posterior mandible.
effective_dosage: 830 nm, 86 mW, 92.1 J/cm², 0.25 J, 3 s/point at 20 points, administered every 48 hours for the first 14 days.
study_duration: 12 weeks (with measurements at 10 days, 3, 6, 9, and 12 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether adding low-level laser therapy (LLLT) to exercise therapy improves pain relief and shoulder range of motion in patients with subacromial syndrome compared to exercise therapy alone.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT combined with exercise therapy significantly improved pain reduction and shoulder range of motion compared to exercise therapy alone, with statistically significant differences in all measured parameters.
population_specificity: 80 patients with subacromial syndrome (rotator cuff and biceps tendinitis).
effective_dosage: Pulsed infrared laser treatment administered over ten sessions in 2 weeks (specific dosage details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the analgesic and anti-inflammatory effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on pain, swelling, and trismus after surgical removal of impacted lower third molars.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT did not significantly reduce pain, swelling, or trismus compared to the placebo side, with no statistically significant differences observed at any time point.
population_specificity: 20 healthy patients (11 women, 9 men) aged 18-37 with symmetrically impacted lower third molars.
effective_dosage: 5 J/cm² energy density, 810 nm wavelength, 0.5 W output power.
study_duration: Evaluations were made at the 2nd and 7th postoperative days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as an intervention for preventing and treating pressure ulcers.
results_summary: The study included LLLT among various interventions reviewed but did not provide specific results for LLLT alone. The overall findings were part of a broader evaluation of multiple treatments and preventive measures for pressure ulcers.
population_specificity: People at risk of developing pressure ulcers or those with existing pressure ulcers, including older individuals and those with reduced mobility or vascular disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the short-term effects of chiropractic joint manipulation therapy (CMT), low-level laser therapy (LLLT), and their combination on pain and range of motion in cervical facet dysfunction.
results_summary: LLLT showed significant improvements in cervical flexion and pain disability compared to CMT alone, but the combination of CMT and LLLT was more effective than either therapy alone for cervical flexion, rotation, and pain disability.
population_specificity: Ambulatory women aged 18-40 with cervical facet joint pain lasting over 30 days and normal neurologic examination.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) reduces pain during cavity preparation with an Er:YAG laser in pediatric dental patients.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly reduced pain during cavity preparation, with median VAS scores of 1 (LLLT group) compared to 3 (non-LLLT group), and the difference was statistically significant (p<0.01).
population_specificity: 10 children aged 6 to 9 years old with 20 primary molar teeth.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) with other physical methods and drug therapy in treating venous leg ulcers, both surgically and conservatively.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT was ineffective in treating venous leg ulcers, showing no significant benefits in either short-term or long-term healing compared to other methods like compression therapy, HVS, or ultrasound. The conclusion explicitly stated that LLLT is not an efficient physical method for this condition.
population_specificity: Patients with venous leg ulcers, both surgically and conservatively treated.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential benefits of laser-assisted therapy, particularly erbium lasers, in improving outcomes and reducing complications in pediatric dental trauma cases.
results_summary: The study suggests that laser-assisted therapies reduce the need for analgesics and anti-inflammatory medications compared to conventional treatments, with laser anesthesia being a promising area. However, the abstract notes a lack of structured guidelines and limited data on laser-assisted dental trauma therapy.
population_specificity: Children with dental trauma

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential applications of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in paediatric dentistry, focusing on its effectiveness and benefits for various dental procedures in children.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT has gained increasing importance in paediatric dentistry, particularly for soft tissue surgery, caries prevention, and patient comfort, though evidence remains insufficient for the highest standards of evidence-based dentistry.
population_specificity: Children in the context of paediatric dentistry.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and tolerability of Low-Level Laser Therapy as a noninvasive body-sculpting alternative compared to other techniques.
results_summary: Low-Level Laser Therapy was approved for use in the U.S. but was associated with significant adverse events. It was noted as one of the noninvasive treatments with fewer complications than lipoplasty but less effective than HIFU for significant results in a single session.
population_specificity: Nonobese patients requiring modest reduction of adipose tissue.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically evaluate the effects of non-ablative laser irradiation on peripheral nerve morphology, physiology, and function, with a focus on its implications for pain relief through low-level laser therapy.
results_summary: The review identified 44 studies showing that laser irradiation slowed nerve conduction velocity and reduced action potential amplitude in humans, while suppressing evoked action potentials in animals. These effects suggest potential mechanisms for acute pain inhibition and long-term depression of chronic pain.
population_specificity: Animal and human peripheral nerve models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of low-level laser therapy in people with tuberculosis without HIV infection.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings regarding low-level laser therapy's effects, only mentioning it as one of the interventions reviewed.
population_specificity: People with tuberculosis without HIV infection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in improving range of motion and other outcomes for individuals with hand osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT may be useful for improving range of motion in hand osteoarthritis patients, though no significant effects were reported for pain, function, or stiffness.
population_specificity: Individuals with hand osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) with alvogyl and the SaliCept patch in managing alveolar osteitis.
results_summary: LLLT (808 nm, 100 mW, 60 seconds, 7.64 J/cm²) performed significantly better than alvogyl and the SaliCept patch in managing alveolar osteitis, with no statistically significant differences observed between the latter two treatments.
population_specificity: 104 patients referred to a clinic with alveolar osteitis.
effective_dosage: 808 nm, 100 mW, 60 seconds, 7.64 J/cm², repeated after 3 days.
study_duration: 7 days (with assessments at diagnosis, 3 days, and 7 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for non-invasive fat reduction and body contouring, independent of liposuction, and to assess the additional effects of a weight loss supplement.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant reduction in circumference measurements or fat layer thickness with LLLT, and blinded evaluations showed little clinical difference post-treatment. Subjects reported dissatisfaction, and the weight loss supplement did not enhance outcomes.
population_specificity: Five subjects with a BMI ≤ 29 kg/m².
effective_dosage: Three laser treatments per week for 2 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on the use of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) to enhance the proliferation of various cultured cell lines, including stem cells.
results_summary: The review found that LLLT enhances cell proliferation rates by increasing ATP, RNA, and DNA synthesis without cytotoxic effects, with optimal results seen at energy densities of 0.5 to 4.0 J/cm² and wavelengths of 600-700 nm.
population_specificity: Cultured cell lines, including stem cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the mechanisms and clinical applications of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), focusing on its effects at cellular and tissue levels, particularly in neurology-related conditions.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT has broadened medical applications, including wound healing, pain relief, and treatment of neurological conditions like stroke and traumatic brain injury. Mechanisms involve mitochondrial photoreception, leading to increased ATP, ROS, calcium, and nitric oxide, which activate protective gene products.
population_specificity: Animal studies and human clinical trials, particularly in neurology-related conditions (stroke, traumatic brain injury, degenerative brain disease, spinal cord injury, peripheral nerve regeneration).

study_goal: To investigate the thermal effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on skin temperature in healthy participants of varying skin color, age, and gender.
results_summary: LLLT at recommended doses caused negligible temperature changes (<1.5°C) across all skin types. Higher doses, especially with a 200 mW, 810 nm laser, significantly increased skin temperature in dark-skinned participants, sometimes exceeding thermal pain thresholds.
population_specificity: 40 healthy volunteers with varying skin color, age, and gender.
effective_dosage: Six irradiation doses (2-12 J) delivered from a 200 mW, 810 nm laser and a 60 mW, 904 nm laser.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) could reduce pain following cryosurgical treatment of oral leukoplakia.
results_summary: The LLLT group reported less pain compared to the non-LLLT group, with no recurrence observed during the 9-month follow-up. The study concluded that LLLT is effective in reducing post-surgical pain from cryosurgical treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with oral leukoplakia undergoing cryosurgical treatment (10 in the non-LLLT group, 8 in the LLLT group).
effective_dosage: 1.4 J per point (49 J/cm² per point), 3 points irradiated per session, immediately post-treatment and at 48 and 72 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) and aluminum hydroxide (AH) in preventing oral mucositis (OM) in patients undergoing radiotherapy or radiochemotherapy for head and neck cancer.
results_summary: The LLLT group showed lower mean oral toxicity and pain scores during radiotherapy, with a significant difference in pain at the 13th session. LLLT was more effective than AH in delaying severe OM, and neither treatment required RT interruption.
population_specificity: 25 patients with head and neck cancer undergoing radiotherapy or radiochemotherapy.
effective_dosage: 830 nm, 15 mW, 12 J/cm² daily before each RT session for 5 consecutive days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) accelerates the healing of chronic diabetic foot ulcers compared to placebo.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced ulcer size by week 4 and resulted in more patients achieving complete healing (8 vs. 3 in placebo) after 20 weeks, though the time difference for complete healing was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 23 patients with diabetic foot ulcers persisting for at least 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) could improve tissue repair and reduce postoperative dehiscences in neonates with myelomeningocele after corrective surgery.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly reduced surgical wound dehiscences (7.69% vs. 17.39%) in neonates, improved healing, shortened hospital stays, and lowered costs.
population_specificity: Neonates with myelomeningocele undergoing corrective surgery at birth.
effective_dosage: Diode laser CW, λ = 685 nm, p = 21 mW, 0.19 J per point, total 4-10 J per patient.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in patients with carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) compared to placebo.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT showed significant improvements in pain intensity, grip strength, symptom severity, and functional status scores compared to baseline, but there was no significant difference between active laser groups and placebo. Only sensorial nerve velocity in the palmar region improved significantly in active laser groups.
population_specificity: Sixty patients with carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).
effective_dosage: 1.2 J/per painful point (group 1) and 0.6 J/per painful point (group 2), 5 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLL) could reduce severe oral mucositis and radiation therapy interruptions in head-and-neck cancer patients undergoing chemoradiotherapy.
results_summary: LLL therapy did not significantly reduce severe oral mucositis, though a marginal benefit could not be excluded. However, it reduced radiation therapy interruptions due to mucositis compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Head-and-neck cancer patients (squamous cell carcinoma or undifferentiated carcinoma of the oral cavity, pharynx, larynx, or neck metastases with unknown primary) undergoing adjuvant or definitive chemoradiotherapy.
study_duration: Duration of chemoradiotherapy (conventional RT 60-70 Gy, 1.8-2.0 Gy/day, 5 times/week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 850-nm Ga-As-Al laser therapy was more effective than placebo in reducing pain, improving range of motion, and decreasing disability in patients with subacromial impingement syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that while both the laser and placebo groups showed statistically significant improvements in pain, range of motion (except external rotation in the placebo group), and disability scores, there was no significant difference between the two groups, indicating no superiority of laser therapy over placebo.
population_specificity: 52 patients (33 females, 19 males; mean age 53.59 ± 11.34 years) with subacromial impingement syndrome.
effective_dosage: 5 joule/cm² at each point over maximum 5-6 painful points for 1 minute, 5 times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy versus occlusal splints in treating myofascial pain dysfunction syndrome.
results_summary: Low-level laser therapy (820 nm, 3 J/cm², 300-mW output power) was found to be as effective as occlusal splints in reducing pain and improving mandibular movement, with both treatments showing statistically significant improvements in vertical movements and reduced muscle tenderness.
population_specificity: 40 patients (34 women, 6 men; mean age 32.84 years) diagnosed with myofascial pain dysfunction syndrome.
effective_dosage: 3 J/cm², 300-mW output power, applied twice weekly for 10 sessions.
study_duration: 10 sessions over approximately 5 weeks (assuming twice weekly).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether low-level laser therapy (LLLT) could prevent oral mucositis (OM) in patients undergoing hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT).
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced OM incidence, with 57.1% of treated patients showing no OM (grade 0) compared to only 4.8% in the control group. The therapy also reduced the severity of OM, with fewer patients experiencing higher-grade symptoms.
population_specificity: 42 patients who underwent autologous or allogeneic HSCT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) could enhance muscle performance in physical strength training compared to strength training alone.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly increased muscle performance, with a 55% improvement in the 1RM leg-press test for the LLLT group compared to 26% in the training-only group. LLLT was also the only group to show improved performance in isokinetic dynamometry, though thigh perimeter increases were similar between LLLT and training-only groups.
population_specificity: 36 clinically healthy men (20.8±2.2 years old) with beginner to moderate physical activity levels.
effective_dosage: 50.4 J total energy (808 nm infrared laser, six diodes of 60 mW each) applied over 140 s per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) applied postoperatively has an antianesthetic effect, potentially increasing pain in the first hours after surgery.
results_summary: The abstract suggests limited evidence supports the antianesthetic effects of LLLT, but it highlights potential benefits like microcirculation activation and analgesic effects. Further experimental and clinical studies are needed to investigate LLLT's impact on anesthesia duration.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing surgery (specific population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of low-level laser irradiation on the secretory function of salivary glands in patients with xerostomia.
results_summary: The study found that low-level laser therapy increased salivary secretion linearly over the 10-day treatment period, with a measurable improvement from 0.05 mL/min to 0.13 mL/min. The control group showed no sustained correlation between therapy duration and salivary output.
population_specificity: 34 patients with xerostomia (dry mouth).
effective_dosage: 904 nm pulsed Ga-As laser, 246 mW/cm² irradiance, 120 sec per daily treatment, average energy density 29.5 J/cm².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in improving mandibular movements and reducing painful symptoms in individuals with temporomandibular disorders (TMD).
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly improved painful symptoms and increased the range of mandibular movements in the treated group compared to the placebo group, with effects persisting 30 days after the last application. No such improvements were observed in the placebo group.
population_specificity: 40 patients with temporomandibular disorders (TMD), divided into two groups of 20 each.
effective_dosage: GaAlAs laser λ 830 nm, 40 mW, 5J/cm², applied twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as an adjunct to non-surgical periodontal therapy in smoking and non-smoking patients with moderate to advanced chronic periodontitis.
results_summary: LLLT significantly improved sulcus bleeding index, clinical attachment level, and probing depth compared to the control group, with notable benefits in smokers. Biomarker levels (e.g., TGF-β1, MMP-1/TIMP-1 ratio) showed significant changes post-treatment, though no intergroup differences were observed.
population_specificity: 36 systemically healthy patients (18 smokers, 18 non-smokers) with moderate to advanced chronic periodontitis.
effective_dosage: 808 nm GaAlAs diode laser, 4 J/cm² energy density applied on days 1, 2, and 7 post-treatment.
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 1, 3, and 6 months post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-term effects of combining photodynamic therapy with low-level laser therapy as an adjunct to nonsurgical treatment of chronic periodontitis.
results_summary: The study found that the combination therapy led to greater reductions in bleeding on probing, probing depth, and interleukin-1β levels at 1 month compared to control, but no significant differences were observed at 3 months.
population_specificity: Twenty-four nonsmoking adults with untreated chronic periodontitis.
effective_dosage: One course of adjunctive photodynamic therapy and low-level laser therapy within 5 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing experimental evidence on Ultra Low-Level Laser Therapy (ULLLT) and explore its biophysical mechanisms and therapeutic potential.
results_summary: The study found that ULLLT (670 nm, 0.45 mJ/cm²) stimulated NGF-induced neurite elongation in neural cells, protected against oxidative stress, and demonstrated anti-edema and anti-hyperalgesia effects in rats. Clinical studies reported beneficial effects in treating musculoskeletal disorders.
population_specificity: Cultured neural cells, animal models (rats), and clinical trials involving musculoskeletal disorder patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) among various physical and rehabilitation interventions for chronic low back pain.
results_summary: The study found insufficient data to draw firm conclusions on the clinical effect of LLLT for chronic low back pain, with only three randomized controlled trials meeting inclusion criteria and overall low-quality evidence.
population_specificity: Adults (≥ 18 years) with chronic (≥ 12 weeks) non-specific low back pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) administered before eccentric exercise could reduce indirect markers of muscle damage.
results_summary: LLLT significantly attenuated increases in muscle proteins (LDH and CK) in blood serum and reduced muscle force decline compared to placebo, though muscle soreness (VAS) showed no significant difference between groups.
population_specificity: 36 healthy men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of superpulsed low-level laser therapy (SLLLT) with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and sham laser in treating pain from temporomandibular joint disorders.
results_summary: SLLLT significantly reduced pain scores compared to NSAIDs and sham laser from the fifth day onward, with sustained improvements in mandibular function observed one month post-treatment.
population_specificity: 99 patients with temporomandibular joint disorders secondary to disc displacement without reduction or osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: SLLLT administered in 10 sessions over 2 weeks; ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for 10 days.
study_duration: 2 weeks of active intervention, with follow-up assessments up to 1 month.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on wound healing in patients with ulcers related to leprosy.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in ulcer surface area, depth, or healing scores between the LLLT and control groups, indicating LLLT provided no additional benefits under the tested parameters.
population_specificity: Patients with leprosy-related ulcers in a leprosy-endemic region of the Brazilian Amazon.
effective_dosage: Treatment administered 3 times per week (specific laser parameters not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the clinical effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on pain relief and functional improvement in patients with acute neck pain and radiculopathy.
results_summary: LLLT provided statistically significant short-term relief of arm pain and improved neck extension compared to placebo, with high effect sizes (d = 0.92 and d = 0.94, respectively). No significant differences were reported for other secondary outcomes like neck disability index or quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients with acute neck pain and radiculopathy.
effective_dosage: Wavelength 905 nm, frequency 5,000 Hz, power density 12 mW/cm², dose 2 J/cm² per session, total dose 12 J/cm² over 15 treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in improving thyroid function and reducing autoantibody levels in patients with chronic autoimmune thyroiditis (CAT).
results_summary: LLLT reduced levothyroxine (LT4) dosage needs in all patients, with 47% not requiring LT4 after 9 months. It also decreased TPOAb levels and increased thyroid parenchymal echogenicity, indicating improved thyroid function.
population_specificity: 15 patients with hypothyroidism caused by CAT, undergoing LT4 treatment.
effective_dosage: 10 applications of LLLT (830 nm, 50 mW) twice a week, with fluence ranging from 38-108 J/cm².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of low-level laser therapy in reducing cervical dentin hypersensitivity compared to a desensitizer and placebo.
results_summary: The study found that low-level laser therapy significantly reduced dentin hypersensitivity over 7 days, with efficacy comparable to a glutaraldehyde-containing desensitizer and superior to placebo. No adverse effects, such as pulp irritation, tooth discoloration, or soft tissue irritation, were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with cervical dentin hypersensitivity (64 teeth included in the study).
study_duration: 7 days (follow-up measurements at 24 hours and 7 days post-treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) with other pain control interventions during fixed orthodontic appliance therapy.
results_summary: LLLT was found to be an effective approach for pain relief, with significantly lower VAS scores (3.30) compared to the control group (7.25). The study did not report adverse effects or safety concerns for LLLT.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing fixed orthodontic appliance therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness and mechanism of 635–680 nm Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as a non-invasive body contouring intervention.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT resulted in a cumulative waist girth loss of 2.15 cm over 4 weeks, with statistically significant cosmetic improvement. In vitro studies suggested fat loss occurred via triglyceride release without lipolysis or cell lysis.
population_specificity: 40 healthy men and women aged 18–65 with BMI <30 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on pain and functional capacity in patients with acute and chronic low back pain caused by lumbar disk herniation (LDH).
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in pain severity, functional capacity, and range of motion in all groups, but no significant differences were detected between laser and placebo laser treatments for either acute or chronic low back pain.
population_specificity: 80 patients (40 acute, 40 chronic) with low back pain caused by LDH.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on limb volume, shoulder mobility, and hand grip strength in post-mastectomy lymphedema patients.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced limb volume, improved shoulder mobility, and increased hand grip strength compared to placebo, with pronounced effects at 8 and 12 weeks. Approximately 93% of patients showed positive outcomes.
population_specificity: Fifty women with breast cancer-related lymphedema.
effective_dosage: 300 mjoules per point over seven points (1.5 joules/cm²), three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if pre-exercise Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) could enhance biceps muscle performance, delay fatigue, and improve postexercise recovery markers in humans.
results_summary: Active LLLT increased elbow flexion repetitions by 14.5% and time to exhaustion by 8.0% compared to placebo. Biochemical markers (blood lactate, creatine kinase, C-reactive protein) indicated faster recovery with LLLT.
population_specificity: Nine healthy male volleyball players.
effective_dosage: 6 J per application location (2 locations, total 60 J), applied once before exercise.
study_duration: Single session (30 seconds of irradiation per location).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare light distribution differences between flat end fiber and cylindrical light diffuser during intravascular low-level laser therapy (ILLLT).
results_summary: The study found that using a cylindrical light diffuser resulted in a more even distribution of laser energy, irradiating a larger volume of blood cells while reducing power density (100 mW/cm² vs. 5000 mW/cm² with flat end fiber), minimizing potential damage.
population_specificity: Not specified (simulation-based study).
effective_dosage: 5 mW laser output, 400 μm fiber diameter.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and potential benefits of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) and laser surgery as a treatment for Bisphosphonate-related osteonecrosis of the jaw (BRONJ).
results_summary: The study found that LLLT and laser surgery are promising for BRONJ treatment, improving reparative processes, bone matrix formation, and tissue healing, with bactericidal and biostimulatory effects. However, long-term prospective studies are needed to confirm efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with Bisphosphonate-related osteonecrosis of the jaw (BRONJ).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (GaAlAs) accelerates bone regeneration in the midpalatal anterior suture after surgically assisted rapid maxillary expansion.
results_summary: The study found that laser therapy significantly increased bone mineralization (26.3%, P < .001) compared to the control group, though optical density measurements after 7 months remained lower than preoperative levels.
population_specificity: 13 patients aged 18-33 with maxillary transverse deficiency (≥7.0 mm).
effective_dosage: 8.4J per point (140J/cm²), 3 points per session (total 25.2J, 420J/cm²), 8 sessions at 48-hour intervals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy on pain reduction and functional improvement in the hands of patients with rheumatoid arthritis.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences between the laser therapy and placebo groups for most measurements, except for a few isolated variables favoring either group. The authors concluded that low-level laser therapy was ineffective at the tested parameters for treating hand symptoms in rheumatoid arthritis patients.
population_specificity: 82 patients with rheumatoid arthritis
effective_dosage: 785 nm wavelength, 3 J/cm² dose, 70 mW mean power

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and meta-analyze the therapeutic effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on lateral epicondylitis (LE), comparing its application on acupuncture points versus tender and myofascial trigger points.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT applied to tender points or myofascial trigger points effectively improved pain relief, grip strength, range of motion, and weight test outcomes, with statistically significant results (p < 0.05). Meta-analysis of three articles showed notable effect sizes for pain reduction post-treatment and at follow-up.
population_specificity: Patients with lateral epicondylitis (LE).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a 660-nm diode laser in preventing and treating oral mucositis in head and neck cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy and chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that laser therapy significantly reduced the incidence and severity of oral mucositis and pain compared to the control group, with differences evident from week 1 and stabilizing by week 7.
population_specificity: 72 head and neck cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy and chemotherapy at the Cancer Hospital of Mato-Grosso, Brazil.
effective_dosage: 660-nm diode laser, 30 mW power, 2 mm spot size, 2 J per point, administered twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the clinical effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for tendinopathy and evaluate the relevance of irradiation parameters and dosage recommendations.
results_summary: The study found conflicting results, with 12 trials showing positive effects and 13 inconclusive or showing no effect. Positive outcomes were associated with recommended dosages, particularly in lateral epicondylitis (improved grip strength) and Achilles tendinopathy (reduced pain).
population_specificity: Patients with tendinopathy (specific conditions included lateral epicondylitis and Achilles tendinopathy).
effective_dosage: Dosages resembling current recommended guidelines (specific amounts not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as an additional treatment improves clinical outcomes in patients with acute low back pain (LBP) with radiculopathy.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in pain intensity, lumbar movement, disability, and quality of life in patients treated with LLLT alongside nimesulide, compared to those treated with nimesulide alone or with placebo LLLT. The largest improvements were observed in the group receiving active LLLT.
population_specificity: 546 patients with acute low back pain and radiculopathy.
effective_dosage: Wavelength 904 nm; frequency 5000 Hz; 100-mW average diode power; power density of 20 mW/cm²; dose of 3 J/cm²; treatment time 150 sec per session, totaling 12 J/cm² per session. Administered 5 times weekly for 15 treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a low-nickel diet on GERD symptoms and determine if nickel patch testing could predict diet responsiveness.
results_summary: Nearly all participants (95%) reported reduced GERD symptoms after 8 weeks on a low-nickel diet, with significant declines in GERD-HRQL, regurgitation, and heartburn scores. Patch test results did not correlate with diet responsiveness.
population_specificity: 20 refractory GERD patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on plantar fasciitis by assessing changes in plantar fascia thickness via ultrasonography and pain reduction using a visual analogue scale (VAS).
results_summary: LLLT significantly improved pain scores (after night rest and daily activities) compared to placebo, though changes in plantar fascia thickness were insignificant between groups. The pain reduction was statistically significant, suggesting LLLT may aid in healing and pain management for plantar fasciitis.
population_specificity: 30 individuals with unilateral plantar fasciitis (25 completed the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether infrared Low-Level Laser Therapy (830 nm) improves postsurgical scarring outcomes after inguinal-hernia surgery.
results_summary: The experimental group receiving LLLT showed significantly better scar appearance, reduced thickness, improved malleability, and lower pain scores compared to the control group at 6 months post-surgery.
population_specificity: 28 patients who underwent inguinal-hernia surgery.
effective_dosage: 830-nm diode laser, 40 mW continuous power, 0.08 cm² spot size, 26 s per point, 1.04 J per point, 13 J/cm² energy density, 10 points per scar, applied on days 1, 3, 5, and 7 post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a low-Nickel diet alone or combined with probiotics on Nickel sensitivity and urinary dysbiosis markers in patients with systemic nickel allergy syndrome (SNAS).
results_summary: The study found that a low-Nickel diet significantly improved Nickel sensitivity and dysbiosis levels, with greater improvements observed when combined with specific probiotic supplementation compared to diet alone.
population_specificity: 51 patients with SNAS and concomitant intestinal dysbiosis.
effective_dosage: Not specified for the diet; probiotics were administered based on dysbiosis type (Lactobacilli, Bifidobacteria, or both).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how dietary protein restriction, particularly deficiencies in leucine and arginine, affects intestinal epithelial mTORC1 signaling, gut microbiota, and the severity of colitis in mice.
results_summary: Protein restriction worsened colitis severity, with arginine deficiency showing significant negative effects. Gut microbiota alterations contributed to disease exacerbation, partially mitigated by antibiotic treatment.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice with induced colitis.
effective_dosage: Control (20% protein), low protein (4% protein), and selective amino acid-deficient diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of the Plant-Dominant Low-Protein Diet (PLADO) in managing chronic kidney disease (CKD) by assessing its impact on renal function, cardiovascular health, and systemic inflammation.
results_summary: PLADO was found to delay CKD progression, reduce dialysis dependence, and mitigate cardiovascular risks through lower dietary acid load, increased fiber intake, and anti-inflammatory properties. It also supported gut microbiota diversity and reduced uremic toxin production, though concerns remain about protein sufficiency and potassium management.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of adding protease (PRO) and Bacillus coagulans (BC) to low-protein (LPRO) diets on the growth performance of broiler chickens.
results_summary: LPRO diets reduced growth performance in broiler chickens, but adding PRO or PRO+BC (PAB) significantly improved growth, amino acid absorption, and intestinal health.
population_specificity: One-day-old broiler chickens (432 total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a low-nickel diet could improve chronic nickel dermatitis and whether nickel excretion levels correlated with symptom changes.
results_summary: The study found that 9 of 17 patients with nickel-aggravated dermatitis improved on a low-nickel diet, with symptoms recurring in 7 of these patients upon resuming a normal diet. Nickel excretion decreased during the diet, but no significant difference was observed between patients who improved and those who did not.
population_specificity: 28 patients with chronic nickel dermatitis, 17 of whom experienced aggravation from oral nickel exposure.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary intervention, no fixed dosage mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether coated sodium butyrate (CSB) could prevent intestinal barrier injury induced by a high-energy and low-protein (HELP) diet in laying hens and explore the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: CSB improved the laying rate, mitigated intestinal barrier dysfunction, reduced inflammatory responses, reshaped gut microbiota, and decreased metabolites linked to inflammation in hens fed the HELP diet.
population_specificity: 28-week-old Huafeng laying hens
effective_dosage: 500 mg/kg CSB added to the HELP diet

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of a low-protein diet in delaying or averting the need for renal replacement therapy in patients with moderate to advanced CKD.
results_summary: The study found that a low-protein diet, particularly one emphasizing plant-based foods, is associated with reduced risk of ESKD and death, as well as lower progression of CKD and its complications. Clinical guidelines support its use in metabolically stable patients with moderate to advanced CKD.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate to advanced non-dialysis dependent chronic kidney disease (NDD-CKD) who are metabolically stable.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate "AminoApp," an application for dietary self-monitoring in patients with inborn errors of metabolism requiring a low-protein diet.
results_summary: The application was found to be user-friendly, with high usability scores (average 84.9), particularly among healthcare professionals (91.6). Initial results suggest promise for aiding metabolic control and treatment adherence, though further research is needed.
population_specificity: Patients with inborn errors of metabolism on a low-protein diet, their caregivers, and healthcare professionals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a low-protein diet could alleviate rheumatoid arthritis symptoms by modulating macrophage polarization and the NRF2/SIRT3/SOD2 pathway.
results_summary: The study found that a low-protein diet significantly reduced RA symptoms, decreased pro-inflammatory cytokines, inhibited M1 macrophage polarization, and promoted M2 macrophage shift via the NRF2/SIRT3/SOD2 pathway, reducing mitochondrial ROS production. NRF2 knockdown abolished these effects, confirming its central role.
population_specificity: Arthritic transgenic K/BxN mice and naive mice used to establish a rheumatoid arthritis model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a low-protein diet on growth performance, nitrogen retention, mineral absorption, and antioxidant activity in medium-growing yellow-feathered broilers.
results_summary: The low-protein diet (19% CP) improved nitrogen retention, increased serum P, Cu, and Mn levels, enhanced liver and heart antioxidant activity, and altered mineral excretion patterns without affecting growth performance.
population_specificity: Medium-growing yellow-feathered male broilers (1-day-old).
effective_dosage: Dietary crude protein levels of 21% (control) and 19% (low-protein).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of additional physical exercise on nutritional status and disease progression indicators in non-dialysis chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients compared to a low-protein diet (LPD) alone.
results_summary: The study found that combining physical exercise with LPD reduced serum creatinine and blood pressure in CKD patients, with resistance exercise improving eGFR and longer exercise duration increasing VO2peak.
population_specificity: Non-dialysis chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients (N = 250).
study_duration: Up to 24 weeks for physical exercise interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of a low-protein diet supplemented with ketoanalogues in reducing proteinuria and slowing the decline of kidney function in patients with advanced diabetic kidney disease.
results_summary: The study found that the low-protein diet supplemented with ketoanalogues reduced proteinuria by 3-fold and slowed the decline in eGFR by 5-fold, effectively postponing the need for kidney replacement therapy without any reported deaths or KRT initiations.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced diabetic kidney disease (stable proteinuria > 3 g/g and eGFR < 30 mL/min) who had good nutritional status and agreed to a low-protein diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the influence of a low-protein diet on chronic kidney disease progression and its potential to delay dialysis.
results_summary: The study found that a low-protein diet, including artificial low-protein foods like wheat starch, can improve high-quality protein intake, ensure adequate energy, and reduce kidney burden in CKD patients.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).

study_goal: To evaluate the efficacy of oral disulfiram and a low-nickel diet in reducing symptoms and preventing relapse of hand eczema in nickel-sensitive individuals.
results_summary: 90.9% of patients treated with disulfiram and a low-nickel diet experienced complete healing of hand eczema during treatment, compared to 10% in the placebo group. Mild relapse occurred in 5 patients during follow-up.
population_specificity: 21 patients (15 females, 6 males) with chronic vesicular hand eczema and nickel sensitivity.
effective_dosage: Not specified for the low-nickel diet; disulfiram was administered orally for 4 weeks.
study_duration: Low-nickel diet started 2 weeks before disulfiram therapy and continued through follow-up; disulfiram was given for 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety of a low-protein diet (LPD) in older adults with advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in survival or nutritional status decline for patients prescribed an LPD (≤0.8 g/kg ideal bodyweight or <0.6 g/kg). However, older age (>75 years), lower nutritional status, and higher comorbidity burden showed significant interactions with LPD for mortality and nutritional decline.
population_specificity: Older adults (≥65 years) with advanced CKD (estimated glomerular filtration rate <20 ml/min/1.73 m²) in six European countries.
effective_dosage: ≤0.8 g/kg ideal bodyweight and <0.6 g/kg ideal bodyweight.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects of Lactiplantibacillus plantarum FRT4 on fatty liver hemorrhage syndrome (FLHS) in laying hens induced by a high-energy low-protein (HELP) diet, focusing on liver lipid metabolism and gut microbiota.
results_summary: Lp. plantarum FRT4 improved laying performance, reduced liver lipid accumulation by regulating lipid metabolism and gut microbiota, and influenced glycerophospholipid metabolism, suggesting a role in mitigating FLHS via the "gut-liver" axis.
population_specificity: Laying hens (caged egg production)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a low-protein diet (LPD) and the Mediterranean diet on renal function preservation in CKD patients using propensity score analysis to balance observational data.
results_summary: Unmatched analysis initially suggested significant renal function preservation with LPD, but this correlation disappeared after propensity score analysis, indicating no significant differences between the two diets. The study highlights the importance of balancing observational data to avoid biased results.
population_specificity: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of berberine (BBR) on fatty liver hemorrhagic syndrome (FLHS) induced by a high-energy, low-protein (HELP) diet and explore the involvement of gut microbiota and bile acid metabolism.
results_summary: BBR supplementation alleviated liver injury and hepatic steatosis, regulated gut microbial composition (increased Actinobacteria and Romboutsia), altered bile acid profiles, and modulated genes related to glucose metabolism, lipid synthesis, and bile acid synthesis.
population_specificity: 90 healthy 140-day-old Hy-line laying hens

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the therapeutic potential of a low-protein diet (LPD) in improving metabolic health and treating lipoatrophic diabetes in a mouse model.
results_summary: A 14-day LPD (5.1% kcal from protein) improved postprandial blood glucose, insulin resistance, and glucose tolerance in lipodystrophy mice, linked to brown adipose tissue (BAT) activation and increased energy expenditure. BAT denervation attenuated these benefits but did not affect weight loss.
population_specificity: Adipose-specific insulin receptor knockout (IRFKO) mice, a model for lipoatrophic diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of low-protein diets in slowing CKD progression and reducing dialysis need, integrating evidence from randomized trials and observational studies.
results_summary: Randomized trials show limited benefits of low-protein diets in nonselected CKD populations, while observational studies suggest broader effectiveness with flexible approaches. Guidelines recommend early implementation, but generalizability is limited due to insufficient data on specific subpopulations.
population_specificity: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients, including diabetic, obese, very old, nephrotic, and pregnant patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a keto-supplemented low-protein diet (sLPD) improves nutritional status in peritoneal dialysis (PD) patients compared to a standard low-protein diet (LPD).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that sLPD significantly improved serum albumin, BMI, and serum prealbumin levels in PD patients compared to LPD, with benefits observed across different PD durations and treatment courses.
population_specificity: Individuals undergoing peritoneal dialysis (PD).
study_duration: Varied (subgroup analyses included PD durations of less than 12 months, 12-24 months, and more than 24 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and clinical/economic impact of a very low-protein diet (sVLPD) supplemented with essential amino acids (without ketoanalogues) in delaying dialysis initiation for stage 5 chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients.
results_summary: The sVLPD slowed CKD progression (mean eGFR 11.6 vs. 9.3 mL/min/1.73 m²) and delayed dialysis initiation (adjusted HR = 0.361) without malnutrition, while reducing healthcare costs. Compliant patients showed better outcomes than non-compliant ones.
population_specificity: Stage 5 chronic kidney disease patients.
effective_dosage: 0.3 g protein/day supplemented with essential amino acids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a low-protein diet supplemented with ketoacids versus a conventional low-protein diet on nutritional indices in predialysis CKD patients.
results_summary: The low-protein diet supplemented with ketoacids significantly improved serum total protein, albumin, and triglyceride levels compared to the conventional low-protein diet, indicating better nutritional outcomes.
population_specificity: Predialysis CKD patients (stage 3-5) older than 18 years in Nigeria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a low-salt low-protein diet supplemented with inulin could lower serum toxin levels (IS and PCS) and improve inflammatory status in CKD patients.
results_summary: The study found that adding inulin to a low-protein diet significantly reduced PCS and IS levels and decreased inflammation markers in predialysis CKD patients, with notable differences compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 45 patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of low-protein diets, particularly plant-based ones, in managing chronic kidney disease (CKD) and their impact on kidney outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that a vegetarian, very low-protein diet reduced the risk of kidney failure in advanced CKD patients without increasing hyperkalemia. Plant-based diets may also reduce uremic toxins, correct metabolic acidosis, and prevent vascular calcification.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), particularly those with advanced stages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between a low-protein diet (LPD) and depressive symptoms as well as health-related quality of life (HRQOL) in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The study found that an LPD was significantly associated with higher odds of depressive symptoms and poor HRQOL in CKD patients, particularly in subgroups with diabetic kidney disease (DKD) and advanced CKD.
population_specificity: 571 CKD patients, categorized into mild CKD, advanced CKD, DKD, and non-DKD subgroups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the therapeutic potential of a low-protein diet (LPD) in improving metabolic health and treating lipoatrophic diabetes in a mouse model.
results_summary: A 14-day LPD (5.1% kcal from protein) improved postprandial blood glucose, insulin resistance, and glucose tolerance in lipodystrophy mice, linked to brown adipose tissue (BAT) activation and increased energy expenditure. BAT denervation attenuated these benefits but did not affect weight loss.
population_specificity: Adipose-specific insulin receptor knockout (IR FKO) mice, modeling lipoatrophic diabetic patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between a low-protein diet (LPD) and renal outcomes, specifically the risk of renal replacement therapy (RRT) and all-cause mortality in stage 4 and 5 CKD patients.
results_summary: The study found that an LPD of 0.5 g/kg/day or less was significantly associated with a lower risk of RRT and all-cause mortality, suggesting it may delay the need for RRT in advanced CKD patients. No dietary supplementation with essential amino acids or ketoanalogues was used.
population_specificity: 325 patients with CKD stage 4 and 5 (eGFR ≥10 mL/min/1.73 m²), primarily diagnosed with chronic glomerulonephritis, nephrosclerosis, or diabetic nephropathy.
effective_dosage: Group 1: <0.5 g/kg ideal body weight/day; Group 2: 0.5–0.6 g/kg/day; Group 3: 0.6–0.8 g/kg/day; Group 4: ≥0.8 g/kg/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the perinatal rat pancreas transcriptome and identify regulatory pathways affected by a low-protein diet (LP) compared to a control diet (CO).
results_summary: The LP diet induced changes in transcripts related to RNA transcription, gene regulation, cell migration, and apoptosis, while downregulating genes like Neurog3, Etv5, and Gas6. The CO group showed enrichment in metabolic pathways related to sterol and lipid metabolism.
population_specificity: Perinatal rats (embryonic day 20 and postnatal days 0 and 2).
study_duration: From embryonic day 20 to postnatal day 2.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a low-protein diet supplemented with ketoacids (LPD + KA) could improve muscle wasting in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The study found that hemoglobin and albumin levels improved in the LPD + KA group, and body mass index and total body water index increased more in this group compared to the conventional LPD group. However, no statistically significant improvements were observed in body fat%, skeletal muscle mass index, or appendicular skeletal muscle mass index.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a ketoanalogue supplemental low-protein diet (sLPD) could reduce the risks of dialysis among CKD stage 4 patients.
results_summary: The study found that patients continuing ketosteril treatment for more than three months had a significantly lower incidence of end-stage kidney disease requiring dialysis (6.8% vs. 10.4%) compared to the discontinuation group, without increasing cardiovascular events, infections, or mortality.
population_specificity: Patients aged >20 years with stage 4 chronic kidney disease (CKD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the cost-effectiveness and health outcomes of a ketoanalogue-supplemented vegetarian very low-protein diet (sVLPD) versus a conventional low-protein diet (LPD) in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) stages 4-5.
results_summary: The sVLPD increased survival and quality-adjusted life years (QALYs) at a lower cost than the LPD in both Taiwan and Thailand, demonstrating its cost-effectiveness and clinical benefits for delaying dialysis initiation.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) stages 4-5 in Taiwan and Thailand.
effective_dosage: sVLPD (0.3-0.4 g/kg-day, vegetarian diet) supplemented with ketoanalogues (1 tablet/5 kg-day); LPD (0.6 g/kg-day, mixed proteins).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a low-protein diet supplemented with α-ketoacid (LKD) could delay chronic kidney disease (CKD) progression by modulating gut microbiota and fecal metabolism in nephrectomized mice.
results_summary: Both LKD and low-protein diet (LPD) alleviated renal failure, fibrosis, and inflammation in nephrectomized mice, with LKD showing superior effects. LKD improved gut microbiome diversity, altered specific microbial abundances, and influenced fecal metabolome, suggesting a potential mechanism for CKD amelioration.
population_specificity: 5/6 nephrectomized mice (a model for chronic kidney disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of low-protein diets balanced with four amino acids on growth performance, meat quality, and cecal microflora in finishing pigs.
results_summary: The study found that low-protein diets (LP and VLP) did not negatively affect growth performance but improved intramuscular fat content, altered fatty acid and amino acid composition, and modified cecal microbiota profiles. The VLP diet also reduced certain biogenic amines in muscle and showed changes in cecal microflora abundance.
population_specificity: Finishing pigs (Duroc × Landrace × Yorkshire) with an average body weight of 70.12 ± 4.03 kg.
effective_dosage: Not specified (diets included normal protein, low protein, and very low protein).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of rumen-protected methionine and lysine (RML) in a low-protein diet on lipid metabolism, m6A RNA methylation, and fatty acid profiles in lambs.
results_summary: The study found that RML supplementation in a low-protein diet reduced plasma leptin, triglyceride, and non-esterified FA levels, altered fatty acid profiles in the liver, and increased m6A RNA methylation levels, suggesting modulation of fat metabolism.
population_specificity: Sixty-three male lambs divided into three treatment groups.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary CP levels: 14.5% for NP, 12.5% for LP, and LP + RML).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of a low-protein diet combined with N-acetylcysteine, taurine, and pyridoxamine in retarding the progression of non-diabetic chronic kidney disease.
results_summary: The study found that the NP group (N-acetylcysteine + pyridoxamine) showed a significant increase in eGFR compared to the control group, particularly in patients with baseline eGFR >45 ml/min and those without metabolic acidosis. The low-protein diet combined with these supplements appeared effective in slowing CKD progression.
population_specificity: Non-dialysis, non-diabetic patients with chronic renal failure (GFR 15-60 ml/min/1.73m²).
effective_dosage: Low-protein diet (0.6g protein per kg body weight) with 25-30 Kcal/kg/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combining a low-protein diet (LPD) with probiotics (Bifidobacterium longum and Lactobacillus reuteri) could reduce uremic, microbiota-derived, and proatherogenic toxins in advanced CKD patients.
results_summary: The study found that LPD alone reduced blood urea nitrogen, total cholesterol, and triglycerides after 2 months. Probiotics supplementation further showed a trend in reducing microbiota-derived toxins and allowed a reduction in antihypertensive and diuretic medications, while the placebo group exhibited increased serum toxins.
population_specificity: Sixty patients with advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD).
study_duration: 2 months of LPD, followed by 3 months of probiotics or placebo.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the mechanisms of protein-energy wasting (PEW), assess nutritional status methods, and evaluate the effectiveness of diets with varying protein content in elderly patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The study found that limiting protein to 0.6 g/kg/day could reduce uremic dyspepsia risk and slow CKD progression, but results were mixed, with some studies showing ineffectiveness in CKD patients with diabetes and a risk of malnutrition.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (over 70 years) with CKD stages 3B-5 and protein-energy wasting (PEW).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of low-protein diets (17.6% and 15.5% crude protein) on growth performance, diarrhoea incidence, and transcriptomic responses in weaned pigs.
results_summary: The 17.6% CP diets (soy protein concentrate and soybean meal) showed similar growth and diarrhoea outcomes, while the 15.5% CP diet reduced weight gain and antibiotic treatments but also lowered blood proteins and altered gut nutrient metabolism genes.
population_specificity: Weaned pigs (from weaning to 30 kg bodyweight).
study_duration: From weaning to 30 kg bodyweight (specific duration not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of maternal low-protein diet as a key factor in the developmental programming of lean type 2 diabetes (T2D).
results_summary: The study found an association between maternal low-protein diet and the lean T2D phenotype, with evidence from observational human studies and animal experiments. Sex-specific disease prevalence was also noted, suggesting further research is needed to understand the etiology and pathophysiology of lean T2D.
population_specificity: Maternal nutrition and its impact on fetal health and adult metabolic outcomes, particularly lean T2D.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a low-protein diet, alone or combined with EGFR inhibitor therapy, could effectively treat intestinal tumors in a Drosophila model.
results_summary: A low-protein diet restored lifespan to control levels in tumor-bearing flies, and when combined with an EGFR inhibitor, it rescued all major tumor-associated phenotypes, even when initiated after full tumor development.
population_specificity: Drosophila (fruit fly) model with EGFR-overexpressing intestinal stem cell tumors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a low-protein diet (LPD) on traditional uremic and atherogenic toxins in advanced CKD patients, focusing on compliance, adherence, and concordance.
results_summary: The study found that LPD significantly reduced nPCR, blood urea nitrogen, cholesterol, and triglycerides. Adherent and concordant patients showed decreased levels of t-PCS, t-IS, and Lp-PLA2, while non-concordant patients experienced increases in these markers.
population_specificity: Fifty-seven adult patients with advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a low-protein diet supplemented with a renal-specific oral nutrition supplement (RONS) could improve nutritional status and delay renal function decline in patients with advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The study found that RONS use increased energy intake, maintained serum albumin and nutritional status, improved quality of life, and slightly preserved residual renal function, though eGFR decreased modestly over time. Body weight and handgrip strength significantly improved after 6 months.
population_specificity: Patients aged 18+ with stage 3b-5 CKD (eGFR 10-45 mL/min/1.73 m²), serum albumin ≥3.0 g/dL, and BMI ≤30 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether maternal late-gestation and nursery piglet diets with varying protein levels influence piglet metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that mismatched maternal and nursery diets (high-low or low-high protein) led to differential gene expression in piglets, with upregulated genes linked to catabolic pathways, lipid metabolism, and inflammation compared to matched diets.
population_specificity: Sows and their piglets (swine model).
effective_dosage: Sows received 12% or 17% crude protein (CP) during late gestation; piglets received 16.5% or 21% CP post-weaning.
study_duration: Last five weeks of gestation for sows; from weaning at 3.5 weeks for piglets (sampled at 4.5 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a low-protein diet supplemented with amino acids and keto acids (sLPD) could safely delay the timing of preemptive kidney transplantation in patients with advanced CKD.
results_summary: The study found that patients on sLPD had a significantly longer duration between advanced CKD diagnosis and transplantation compared to those not on sLPD (345 vs. 220 days), with no difference in post-transplantation adverse events between the groups.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced CKD who underwent their first preemptive kidney transplantation in Taiwan between 2001 and 2017.
study_duration: Median duration of 345 days for sLPD group before transplantation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a low-protein diet (LPD) combined with once-weekly online-hemodiafiltration (OL-HDF) in preserving residual kidney function (RKF) in incident hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The study found that once-weekly OL-HDF combined with LPD (0.6-0.8 g/kg/day on non-dialysis days) was practical and helped preserve RKF in selected patients, with mean RKF remaining stable over 6 and 12 months. The median duration before transitioning to more frequent dialysis was 7 months, primarily due to declining RKF.
population_specificity: Stage 5 CKD patients with residual kidney function ≥ 3 mL/min and urine output ≥ 800 mL/day, initiating hemodialysis at a university-based center in Thailand.
effective_dosage: 0.6-0.8 g/kg/day on non-dialysis days; 1.2 g/kg/day on dialysis days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Lysine supplementation in a low-protein diet on growth performance, skeletal muscle development, and nitrogen utilization in rabbits.
results_summary: The study found that a low-protein diet with 0.3% Lysine supplementation improved growth performance, reduced nitrogen excretion, and enhanced nitrogen utilization. It also modulated gene and protein expression related to muscle development, counteracting some negative effects of the low-protein diet.
population_specificity: 1000 healthy weaned rabbits with an average weight of 938.6 ± 6.54 g.
effective_dosage: 0.15%, 0.3%, or 0.45% Lysine added to the low-protein diet.
study_duration: 7 days of pre-feeding followed by 28 days of treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical benefits of a low-protein diet with ketoanalogues of essential amino acids in minimizing urea accumulation and slowing CKD progression and cardiovascular complications.
results_summary: The study found that a low-protein diet with ketoanalogues reduces urea accumulation and uremic toxins, thereby slowing CKD progression and lowering cardiovascular risks. It also highlighted urea's role in systemic inflammation, vascular dysfunction, and protein carbamylation.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effects of Saroglitazar (SGZ) in a high fat-low protein diet (HFLPD) fed mouse model of metabolic syndrome (MetS) and associated cognitive deficits.
results_summary: SGZ treatment significantly reversed HFLPD-induced metabolic and cognitive alterations, improving glucose and lipid profiles, cerebral glucose homeostasis, BBB integrity, and reducing oxidative stress and neuroinflammation. It also improved locomotion, memory retention, and reduced anxiety-like behaviors in mice.
population_specificity: Adult male C57BL/6J mice
study_duration: 4 weeks (administered from the 12th to 16th week of the study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a low salt, low protein diet supplemented with keto-analogues (sLPD) on salt intake, blood pressure, and cardiovascular events in patients with advanced diabetic kidney disease and heavy proteinuria.
results_summary: The study found that the sLPD reduced salt intake and mean arterial pressure, with 58% of patients achieving the salt intake target. However, blood pressure lower than 130/80 mmHg increased cardiovascular risk but not renal risk in these patients.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced diabetic kidney disease (median eGFR 11.7 ml/min) and heavy proteinuria (median 4.8 g/g creatininuria).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of low-protein diets (LPDs) as a core element of care in managing chronic kidney disease (CKD) and to advocate for their tailored, patient-centered implementation.
results_summary: The study found that LPDs can delay kidney failure and improve quality of life in CKD patients, but their adoption remains limited. It emphasizes the need for careful, individualized prescription to ensure safety and efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with CKD stages 3 to 5 (not on dialysis) who are metabolically stable.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the development and potential health benefits of low-protein processed brown rice (LPBR) for CKD patients, focusing on its nutritional profile and impact on disease progression and quality of life.
results_summary: The study found that LPBR has low protein, potassium, and phosphorus content while maintaining energy levels and providing high dietary fiber, γ-oryzanol, and antioxidant activity, which may improve gut health and slow CKD progression.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), particularly in rice-eating countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Eucommia ulmoides flavones (EUF) could serve as an alternative to antibiotic growth promoters in improving growth performance and intestinal health in weanling piglets fed a low-protein diet.
results_summary: EUF supplementation improved body weight, average daily gain, and feed efficiency while reducing diarrhea incidence. It also enhanced intestinal morphology and increased beneficial bacteria while decreasing harmful coliform bacteria.
population_specificity: Weanling piglets (n = 480)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the accuracy of protein labeling on packaged foods for individuals following a phenylalanine-restricted diet, particularly for patients with phenylketonuria (PKU).
results_summary: The study found widespread inaccuracies in protein labeling on supermarket websites, with 55% of foods having unclear protein content and 43-62% containing misleading, omitted, or erroneous information. These labeling errors could negatively impact metabolic control in PKU patients.
population_specificity: Patients with phenylketonuria (PKU) who rely on accurate protein labeling for dietary management.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on food labeling accuracy, not dosage).
study_duration: Not applicable (study was observational, not an intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a low-protein diet supplemented with ketoanalogues (sLPD) could safely delay dialysis initiation and reduce major adverse cardiac and cerebrovascular events (MACCEs) in patients with very poor renal function (eGFR < 15 mL/min/1.73 m²).
results_summary: The study found that the sLPD group had a lower incidence of new-onset dialysis (40.2% vs. 44.4%) and MACCEs (3.7% vs. 5.9%) compared to the control group, with benefits persisting even in patients with extremely low eGFR (<5 mL/min/1.73 m²).
population_specificity: Patients with estimated glomerular filtration rates (eGFR) < 15 mL/min/1.73 m² in Taiwan.
study_duration: More than 3 months of sLPD, followed for 1 year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of medium-chain fatty acid glyceride supplementation on growth performance and intestinal health in weaned piglets fed a low-protein diet.
results_summary: The study found that medium-chain fatty acid glycerides (tricaprylin + tricaprin and glycerol monolaurate) improved feed intake, intestinal barrier function, and immune markers in piglets on a low-protein diet, with some treatments outperforming antibiotic-supplemented controls.
population_specificity: Weaned piglets
effective_dosage: MCT (tricaprylin + tricaprin) and GML (glycerol monolaurate) at unspecified dosages; antibiotics in PC group (75 mg/kg quinocetone, 20 mg/kg virginiamycin, 50 mg/kg aureomycin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the molecular mechanisms of kidney damage induced by intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) due to a low-protein diet and evaluate the protective effect of ouabain.
results_summary: The study found that a low-protein diet induced IUGR in rat offspring, but ouabain treatment partially reversed body and kidney weight loss and regulated key metabolites, particularly in arginine metabolism, which is crucial for fetal kidney development.
population_specificity: Pregnant rats and their offspring.
study_duration: Intervention administered until the 20th gestational day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of reducing dietary protein while supplementing with limiting amino acids (tryptophan, threonine, and valine) on growth performance, immunity, and carcass traits in broiler chickens.
results_summary: The study found that reducing crude protein by 2% with amino acid supplementation improved final body weight, feed conversion ratio, carcass yield, breast meat quality, and immune parameters while also enhancing economic returns. Blood biochemical markers indicated improved metabolic health, and immune-related gene expression was upregulated.
population_specificity: One-day-old broiler chickens (300 chicks divided into three treatment groups).
effective_dosage: Diets with 22%, 21%, and 20% crude protein (starter phase); 20%, 19%, and 18% (grower phase); 18%, 17%, and 16% (finisher phase), supplemented with threonine, tryptophan, and valine.
study_duration: 35 days (divided into starter [1-14 days], grower [15-28 days], and finisher [29-35 days] phases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of maternal low-protein diet during pregnancy and the periconception period on fetal bone development and quality in mice.
results_summary: The study found that maternal low-protein diet (LPD) increased bone formation with high mineral density in male fetuses at early stages (E14.5), while periconceptional protein restriction (Emb-LPD) led to increased bone growth but reduced mineral density in male fetuses at later stages (E17.5). These effects were sex-specific and linked to placental efficiency changes.
population_specificity: Pregnant mice and their offspring (male and female fetuses).
effective_dosage: Not specified (low-protein diet composition not detailed).
study_duration: Duration of pregnancy (LPD) or exclusively during the preimplantation period (Emb-LPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how a low-protein diet (LPD), with or without inulin supplementation, modulates inflammatory, metabolic, and psychocognitive markers in CKD patients.
results_summary: The study found that LPD with inulin improved glycemic and lipid metabolism, reduced systemic inflammation, and enhanced quality of life and mood in CKD patients, though cognitive function did not significantly improve. Both groups showed reductions in serum nitrogen, phosphorus, and uric acid, as well as improved metabolic acidosis.
population_specificity: CKD patients on conservative therapy (n=41, 18 in intervention group, 23 in control group).
effective_dosage: LPD (0.6 g/kg/day) plus inulin (19 g/day) for the intervention group; LPD alone for controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of varying dietary crude protein (CP) and total sulfur amino acids (TSAA) levels on productive performance, egg quality, and egg components in Lohmann Brown laying hens.
results_summary: The study found that 18% CP diets improved body weight, feed conversion, egg weight, and egg mass, while 16% CP with 0.72% Met+Cys optimized egg production. Most egg quality traits were unaffected by dietary treatments, but CP and Met+Cys interactions influenced moisture and total solids in eggs.
population_specificity: Lohmann Brown laying hens (18-34 weeks old)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a low-protein diet supplemented with key essential amino acids on broiler growth performance, intestinal function, blood metabolites, and nitrogen excretion under different sanitary conditions.
results_summary: The study found that a low-protein diet supplemented with essential amino acids (LPA) maintained growth performance comparable to a high-protein diet under poor sanitary conditions while reducing nitrogen excretion. However, the LP diet alone impaired growth performance and intestinal health compared to HP and LPA diets.
population_specificity: One-day-old male broilers (Ross 308) raised under sanitary or poor sanitary conditions.
