effective_dosage: Not specified (LP diet supplemented with synthetic AA up to required levels).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of a low-protein diet on proximal reflux episodes in patients with laryngopharyngeal reflux (LPR) using multichannel intraluminal impedance-pH monitoring (MII-pH).
results_summary: The study found that a high-fat, low-protein diet was associated with a higher number of proximal reflux episodes. Patients who adhered to a low-fat, high-protein diet showed significant improvements in reflux symptoms and signs.
population_specificity: Patients with LPR symptoms and findings from three European hospitals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a low-protein diet (LPD) with or without the prebiotic inulin on gut microbiota and clinical parameters in chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients.
results_summary: The LPD modified gut microbiota, increased beneficial bacteria, and improved inflammatory and metabolic markers, with additional benefits observed when combined with inulin, such as reduced serum uric acid and C-reactive protein.
population_specificity: 16 CKD patients (9 treated with LPD + inulin, 7 with LPD alone) and 16 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits of nutritional therapy, particularly a very low-protein diet (VLPD), in slowing chronic kidney disease (CKD) progression and improving related metabolic parameters.
results_summary: The study found that VLPD reduces edema, blood pressure, phosphate levels, and drug doses while correcting metabolic acidosis and lowering urea and toxin levels like indoxyl-sulphate. It also slows CKD progression.
population_specificity: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how a periodized low-protein-high-carbohydrate (pLPHC) diet affects metabolic health and gut microbiome (GM) in mice, and whether these effects interact with voluntary exercise.
results_summary: The pLPHC diet protected against weight gain, improved glucose tolerance, and altered the GM (increased Bacteroidetes and Akkermansia). These changes correlated with better metabolic health, while exercise had minimal impact.
population_specificity: Mice
effective_dosage: 5% low-protein-high-carbohydrate diet (periodized 14 days on/14 days off)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the short-term effects of a high-starch, low-protein diet (HSTD) on β-cell mass (BCM) and islet number in mice, and whether these effects could be reversed by returning to a normal chow diet.
results_summary: The study found that a 5-week HSTD increased BCM and islet number in mice, independent of body weight gain. Reverting to a normal chow diet for 2 weeks reversed these changes, bringing BCM and insulin levels back to baseline.
population_specificity: Mice
study_duration: 5 weeks of HSTD followed by 2 weeks of normal chow

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a low-protein diet (LPD) on Nrf2 and NF-κB mRNA expression and oxidative stress markers in nondialysis chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients.
results_summary: The study found that a low-protein diet increased Nrf2 mRNA expression and decreased TBARS levels (a marker of lipid peroxidation), but did not significantly alter NF-κB mRNA expression. The Nrf2/NF-κB ratio increased, suggesting potential modulation of oxidative stress and inflammation.
population_specificity: Nondialysis CKD patients (n=30, age 55.5 ± 14.0 years, BMI 29.1 ± 5.9 kg/m², GFR 35.6 ± 12.2 mL/minute).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of green propolis hydroalcoholic extract on chronic inflammation in mice fed a low-protein diet.
results_summary: Propolis treatment in low-protein diet mice led to weight recovery, maintained serum protein levels, reduced inflammatory infiltrate, and exhibited antiangiogenic effects. In standard protein diet mice, propolis initially lowered red blood cell parameters but later restored them, while increasing monocyte count and TNF levels.
population_specificity: Mice (animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the long-term safety and outcomes of a ketoanalogue-supplemented low-protein diet (sLPD) in patients with end-stage renal disease after commencing dialysis.
results_summary: The sLPD group showed a lower risk of all-cause mortality, major cardiac and cerebrovascular events (MACCEs), and infection-related death compared to the non-sLPD group. The study concluded that sLPD treatment might be safe without long-term negative consequences after dialysis.
population_specificity: Patients with new-onset end-stage renal disease on permanent dialysis in Taiwan (2001-2013).
study_duration: More than 3 months of sLPD treatment in the year preceding dialysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a low-protein diet (LPD) improves renal function in patients with type 1 or 2 diabetic nephropathy through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The study found that LPD did not significantly improve glomerular filtration rate (GFR) or proteinuria in patients with diabetic nephropathy. Subgroup analysis indicated that LPD might even increase proteinuria in type 2 diabetes patients.
population_specificity: Patients with type 1 or 2 diabetic nephropathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a low-protein diet (LPD) on lipid and anthropometric profiles in non-dialysis chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients.
results_summary: After six months of LPD, patients showed significant reductions in BMI, total cholesterol, LDL, and uric acid, along with improved glomerular filtration rate (GFR). The diet also reduced energy, protein, cholesterol, and fiber intake.
population_specificity: Non-dialysis CKD patients (40 participants, 20 men, mean age 62.7 ± 15.2 years, GFR 26.16 ± 9.4 mL/min/1.73m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the progression of renal failure in adult patients with CKD stages 3b and 4 receiving a low-protein diet supplemented with amino acids and ketoanalogues.
results_summary: The study found that the low-protein diet supplemented with ketoanalogues preserved nutritional condition and mineral balance, significantly improved glomerular filtration, and decreased urea levels. Body mass index and albumin levels remained stable over the study period.
population_specificity: Adult patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) stages 3b and 4 (67% male, mean age 59.7 years).
effective_dosage: 0.4-0.6 g/kg/day protein, 30-35 kcal/kg/day, plus 11.87 tablets/day of Ketosteril® (approximately 1 tablet per 5 kg body weight).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether folate supplementation during pregnancy could reverse glucose intolerance and insulin resistance induced by a low-protein diet in adult offspring.
results_summary: Folate supplementation partially reversed glucose intolerance in a sex- and age-dependent manner but did not reverse insulin resistance, worsening it in males by 4 months. The study also found that folate improved pancreatic development in offspring.
population_specificity: Pregnant rats and their offspring.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the post-ruminal effects of feeding ruminants different concentrations of rumen-protected methionine (RPM) in low crude protein diets.
results_summary: RPM supplementation in low crude protein diets improved post-ruminal digestibility and volatile fatty acid production, with higher RPM levels showing effects comparable to high-protein diets.
population_specificity: Dairy ruminants
effective_dosage: Low RPM (LPLM) and high RPM (LPHM) mixed per 20 ± 0.04 g basal diet

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the reno-protective effects of low-protein diets (LPDs), particularly very-low-protein diets (VLPDs), in advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD) and diabetic kidney disease (DKD), focusing on molecular mechanisms and clinical benefits.
results_summary: The study found that LPDs, especially VLPDs, improve renal function by reducing glomerular hyperfiltration/hypertension and restoring autophagy via mTORC1 inhibition, but noted insufficient clinical data on VLPDs for DKD and highlighted risks of malnutrition in CKD patients.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced CKD, including diabetic kidney disease (DKD), and animal models of type 2 diabetes and obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of low-protein diets in reducing kidney failure risk, while addressing methodological challenges in trial analyses.
results_summary: Per-protocol analyses indicated that low protein intake reduces kidney failure risk, but adherence issues and potential malnutrition risks complicate its clinical application. Intensive surveillance is recommended for compliant patients, while non-compliant patients may benefit from higher protein intake to avoid adverse outcomes.
population_specificity: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a maternal low-protein diet on proinflammatory cytokines, reactive oxygen species, and RAS components in adult male offspring kidneys, and whether post-weaning losartan treatment could mitigate these effects.
results_summary: The study found that a maternal low-protein diet led to higher blood pressure, renal RAS activation, immune cell infiltration, and oxidative stress in adult offspring. Post-weaning losartan treatment abolished these adverse effects, suggesting Ang II via the AT1 receptor is critical for pathological initiation.
population_specificity: Pregnant Sprague-Dawley rats and their adult male offspring.
effective_dosage: Low-protein diet (6% casein) during gestation; losartan (10 mg/kg/day) post-weaning.
study_duration: Gestation period for the diet; losartan treatment until 20 weeks of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a low-protein diet could safely and effectively manage chronic kidney disease (CKD) by delaying dialysis initiation and slowing CKD progression without causing protein-energy wasting or cachexia.
results_summary: The study found that low-protein diets (<0.8 g/kg/day) were associated with improved serum bicarbonate and phosphorus levels, reduced azotemia, slower progression to end-stage renal disease, and a trend toward lower all-cause mortality. Very-low-protein diets (<0.4 g/kg/day) showed greater kidney function preservation and further reduced progression to end-stage renal disease, with no increased risk of malnutrition or protein-energy wasting.
population_specificity: Patients with non-dialysis-dependent chronic kidney disease (CKD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a low-protein diet (LPD) supplemented with ketoacids (LPD+KA) on renal outcomes in KKAy mice, an early type 2 diabetic nephropathy model.
results_summary: LPD significantly reduced albuminuria, mesangial expansion, and oxidative stress in diabetic kidneys, with LPD+KA showing even greater benefits compared to LPD alone. Both LPD and LPD+KA slightly reduced body weight but had no significant effect on kidney weight or blood glucose levels.
population_specificity: KKAy mice (early type 2 diabetic nephropathy model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a low-protein diet (LPD) on uremic toxins and gut microbiota in nondialysis chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients.
results_summary: Adherence to LPD (0.7 ± 0.2 g/kg/day) improved renal function (nonsignificantly) and reduced cholesterol levels, while significantly lowering p-cresyl sulfate levels. The gut microbiota profile also changed, with protein intake positively correlating with the number of bacterial bands.
population_specificity: Nondialysis CKD patients (stage 3-4)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a very low-protein diet (VLPD) on reducing acid load in chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients.
results_summary: VLPD significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure, plasma urea, protein and phosphate intake, calcemia, phosphatemia, urinary sodium, potassium, and phosphate, as well as NEAP and PRAL over 6 and 12 months. The study concluded that VLPD effectively reduces acid intake and should be adopted to correct metabolic acidosis in CKD patients.
population_specificity: 146 CKD patients (54 on VLPD, 92 controls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of a maternal low-protein diet during gestation and lactation on milk production in rats, comparing it to a control diet.
results_summary: The study found that maternal dietary protein restriction (59% reduction) led to a 34% decrease in milk flow compared to the control group. The deuterated water (D2O) method provided more precise measurements of milk production than the weight-suckle-weight (WSW) method.
population_specificity: Rat dams (mothers) and their pups in a controlled laboratory setting.
effective_dosage: Not specified (iso-caloric low-protein diet vs. control diet).
study_duration: Administered during gestation and lactation (assessed between days 11 to 14 after pup birth).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of a low-protein diet on circulating FGF21 levels and its role in metabolic adaptation, particularly in relation to obesity treatment.
results_summary: The study found that a low-protein diet increased FGF21 production in mice, leading to body weight reduction without changes in food intake and induced FGF21-dependent browning in subcutaneous white adipose tissue. In humans, an inverse correlation between protein intake and circulating FGF21 levels was observed.
population_specificity: Mice and a subgroup of 78 individuals from the PREDIMED trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of a low-protein diet (LPD) in retarding the progression of chronic kidney disease (CKD) and provide clinical practice recommendations for its application.
results_summary: The study suggests that LPD can significantly slow CKD progression and delay the need for renal replacement therapy, particularly in early-stage CKD (stages 1-3), provided patients have good appetite and nutritional status. The authors argue that previous studies may have underestimated LPD's benefits due to short follow-up periods.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), particularly those in early stages (1-3) or with slowly progressive disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of a low-protein, low-phosphorus, and normal-to-high-energy diet in preserving residual kidney function and improving outcomes in newly transitioned hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The study suggests that combining a low-protein diet with incremental hemodialysis may preserve residual kidney function, improve phosphorus control, and reduce the need for erythropoiesis-stimulating agents. However, long-term safety and efficacy require further validation.
population_specificity: Newly transitioned hemodialysis patients with residual kidney function.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a low-protein diet (less than 0.5 g/kg body weight) and low-protein rice in slowing the progression of chronic kidney disease (CKD) and controlling protein, potassium, and phosphate intake.
results_summary: The study found that a low-protein diet is a very effective intervention for CKD, particularly in slowing disease progression when eGFR falls below 60 ml/min/1.73 m². Low-protein rice was highlighted as helpful for controlling protein, potassium, and phosphate intake, with potential benefits for CKD patients in China and Southeast Asia.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), particularly those with eGFR below 60 ml/min/1.73 m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and effectiveness of a low-protein diet in an illiterate elderly patient with advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The study found that with personalized dietary guidance (translated into images by the patient's daughter), the patient successfully adhered to the low-protein diet, achieving stable kidney function and maintaining adequate nutritional status despite initial challenges.
population_specificity: A 77-year-old illiterate woman with stage 4 CKD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether a one-year low-protein diet could activate autophagy in skeletal muscle and improve muscle pathology in patients with COL6-related myopathies.
results_summary: The low-protein diet increased autophagic markers in skeletal muscle and blood leukocytes, improved muscle homeostasis, and showed no adverse effects on body composition, strength, or function. Metabolic changes suggested enhanced mitochondrial function.
population_specificity: Seven adult patients with COL6-related myopathies (Ullrich congenital muscular dystrophy and Bethlem myopathy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe a practical approach to implementing a low-protein diet (LPD) for nondialysis chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients in Brazil, considering cultural dietary habits and barriers to adherence.
results_summary: The study highlights that successful LPD implementation requires adapting Brazilian dietary habits, reducing portion sizes, and providing adequate food substitutions. Intensive nutritional counseling and early dietetic attention are essential for adherence and better metabolic control in nondialysis CKD patients.
population_specificity: Nondialysis chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients in Brazil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the correlation between a low-protein diet (LPD) and the onset of malnutrition in chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients.
results_summary: The study found that LPD slowed kidney disease progression but worsened nutritional status, evidenced by decreased serum albumin, fat-free mass, muscular mass, and body cell mass, along with increased C-reactive protein.
population_specificity: 41 CKD patients (stages IIIb/IV according to K-DIGO guidelines).
effective_dosage: 0.7 g per kilogram Ideal Body Weight per day of protein.

study_goal: To determine if an individualized low-protein diet improves general condition, slows renal function deterioration, and delays dialysis in CKD patients.
results_summary: The individualized low-protein diet significantly improved diastolic blood pressure, protein intake, renal function markers, and increased albumin and hemoglobin levels compared to baseline and the normal low-protein diet group. It also reduced urine protein levels, with prealbumin being the most relevant factor.
population_specificity: Forty CKD inpatients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a low-protein diet (LPD) with ketoanalogues of amino acids (KA/AA) versus traditional LPD without KA/AA in slowing kidney function decline and improving metabolic parameters in CKD patients.
results_summary: The study found that LPD with KA/AA significantly slowed the decline in GFR, reduced proteinuria, improved lipid metabolism, and maintained hemoglobin levels compared to traditional LPD or no intervention. Patients on LPD with KA/AA also achieved better blood pressure control and fewer required renal replacement therapy.
population_specificity: 63 patients with CKD stages 3-4, primarily with glomerulonephritis, and 30 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether supplementing a low-protein diet with fermentable fibers could alter amino acid metabolism in healthy dogs, potentially providing a model for future studies in dogs with kidney or liver disease.
results_summary: Dogs fed the soluble fiber (SF) diet showed higher fecal excretion of short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) and modified plasma acylcarnitine and amino acid profiles, suggesting a shift toward using SCFAs instead of amino acids for energy. The SF diet significantly increased postprandial plasma concentrations of certain amino acids and SCFA metabolites.
population_specificity: Healthy dogs
effective_dosage: Low-protein (17%) diet supplemented with sugar beet pulp and guar gum mix (SF) or cellulose (IF), with total dietary fiber contents of 9.4% (SF) and 8.2% (IF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent evidence on the relevance of protein-restricted diets in CKD patients, focusing on their relationship with malnutrition and bone/mineral disorders.
results_summary: Protein-restricted diets, especially when supplemented with keto-analogues and closely monitored, do not appear linked to malnutrition, but their effects on bone and mineral disorders require further investigation.
population_specificity: People with chronic kidney disease (CKD) not undergoing kidney replacement therapies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a low-protein diet (LPD) with and without ketoacid (KA) supplementation on autophagy and inflammation in skeletal muscle of chronic kidney disease (CKD) rats.
results_summary: The LPD improved body weight and muscle mass, with greater effects observed in the LPD + KA group. While LPD + KA further enhanced autophagy markers, its impact on inflammation in CKD was less distinct.
population_specificity: Rats with 5/6 nephrectomy (a model for CKD).
effective_dosage: 3 g/kg/day protein (LPD) or 3 g/kg/day protein plus 1% KA (LPD + KA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a low-protein diet (LPD) or very-low protein diet (VLPD) supplemented with ketoanalogues (KA) on renal, metabolic, clinical, and nutritional outcomes in adults with diabetic kidney disease (DKD).
results_summary: The meta-analyses and individual studies showed favorable effects of KA-supplemented LPD/VLPD on renal function, metabolic parameters, clinical outcomes, and nutritional status, with no adverse effects on nutritional status. The regimens were found to be safe and well tolerated.
population_specificity: Adults with non-dialysis dependent diabetic kidney disease (DKD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the utility and challenges of implementing a low-protein diet (LPD) for managing non-dialysis-dependent chronic kidney disease (CKD) in North America.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that LPD (0.6-0.8 g/kg/day) is underutilized in North America due to historical, dietary, and adherence challenges, but there is interest in further research. Adherence monitoring and nutritional supplements may help address protein-energy wasting concerns.
population_specificity: Patients with non-dialysis-dependent chronic kidney disease (CKD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of a low-protein diet in reducing uremic toxins and its potential therapeutic benefits for chronic kidney disease patients.
results_summary: The study suggests that a low-protein diet, along with other dietary and supplement therapies, may help reduce uremic toxins and mitigate associated complications like oxidative stress, inflammation, and organ damage in chronic kidney disease.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how maternal low-protein diets and other nutritional stressors epigenetically affect offspring health, particularly during the preimplantation period.
results_summary: The study found that maternal low-protein diets can induce epigenetic modifications (e.g., DNA methylation, histone changes) that may compromise offspring health later in life, linking such diets to potential long-term metabolic and developmental risks.
population_specificity: Mammalian models (human and animal studies) focusing on maternal nutrition and embryonic development.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of ketoanalogue (KA) supplementation on skeletal muscle mass in elderly patients with stage 4-5 chronic kidney disease (CKD) on a low-protein diet.
results_summary: KA users maintained skeletal muscle and body fat mass, while non-KA users experienced significant muscle mass reduction and fat mass gain, particularly in patients aged ≥68 years.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (mean age 66.5 ± 12.9 years) with stage 4-5 CKD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the renoprotective effects of a low-protein diet (LPD) and its underlying molecular mechanism in a rat model of type 2 diabetes and obesity.
results_summary: The LPD (5.77% protein) improved renal function and histology, particularly tubulointerstitial damage, by restoring autophagy through suppression of the mTORC1 pathway. The diet also partially decreased HbA1c levels without affecting blood pressure.
population_specificity: Diabetic male Wistar fatty (fa/fa) rats (WFRs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of ketoacid supplementation on insulin resistance, systemic inflammation, oxidative stress, and endothelial dysfunction in CKD patients undergoing peritoneal dialysis.
results_summary: Ketoacid therapy had no significant effect on insulin resistance (HOMA-IR) but improved markers of systemic inflammation (hs-CRP) and metabolic balance (leptin/adiponectin ratio) compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 100 CKD patients undergoing peritoneal dialysis at a Chinese center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a low-protein diet (LPD) with and without essential amino acid ketoanalogue supplementation (KA) on serum Klotho, FGF-23 levels, and cardiovascular parameters in CKD patients.
results_summary: The LPD + KA group showed improved FGF-23 and Klotho levels, reduced cardiovascular calcification, and better nutritional status compared to LPD alone, which was associated with increased malnutrition risk and adverse cardiovascular changes.
population_specificity: Non-diabetic CKD patients (stages 3b-4), compliant with LPD (0.6 g/kg/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether prebiotic and probiotic supplementation combined with a low-protein diet could slow the progression of chronic kidney disease (CKD) by reducing uremic toxin accumulation and preserving kidney function.
results_summary: The study found that patients receiving prebiotic and probiotic supplementation alongside a low-protein diet experienced a significantly slower decline in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) compared to those on a low-protein diet alone, suggesting a potential benefit in delaying CKD progression.
population_specificity: 24 stable CKD patients (stage III to V) not on renal replacement therapy.
effective_dosage: 3 tablets of prebiotic + probiotic supplementation daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a low-protein diet combined with creatine supplementation in treating symptoms of GAMT deficiency, particularly epileptic seizures and movement disorders.
results_summary: The study found that a low-protein diet with restricted arginine and increased ornithine, alongside creatine supplementation, improved symptoms of GAMT deficiency, especially epileptic seizures and abnormal movements.
population_specificity: Patients with GAMT deficiency, an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review LSD's potential as a treatment for anxiety, depression, and alcohol use disorder, examining its pharmacokinetics, neurobiological mechanisms, and safety considerations.
results_summary: The study found that LSD significantly reduces symptoms of anxiety, depression, and alcohol use disorder, with long-lasting effects, and shows promise in psychedelic-assisted psychotherapy. However, challenges like small sample sizes and regulatory restrictions limit large-scale trials.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of clinical trials and neurobiological mechanisms).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety and efficacy of repeated low doses of LSD in reducing ADHD symptoms compared with placebo.
results_summary: The study found that LSD was physically safe and psychologically well tolerated but was not more efficacious than placebo in reducing ADHD symptoms, with both groups showing similar improvements in symptom scores.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18 to 65 years with a prior ADHD diagnosis and moderate to severe symptoms.
effective_dosage: 20 μg twice weekly for 6 weeks (total of 12 doses).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate rural-urban differences in the perception of LSD and cannabis risks using national survey data.
results_summary: Rural residents were 1.2 to 1.4 times more likely to perceive using LSD once or twice as of great risk compared to urban residents during the survey period. The study highlights a significant rural-urban divide in LSD risk perception, which could impact policymaking on psychedelic therapies.
population_specificity: National Survey of Drug Use and Health (NSDUH) respondents (2015–2021).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the acute effects of LSD when administered with paroxetine (an SSRI) and assess potential pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic interactions.
results_summary: Paroxetine reduced negative subjective effects of LSD (e.g., "bad drug effect," anxiety, nausea) without altering its pleasant effects. LSD's pharmacokinetics were affected by paroxetine, increasing its concentration, but no dose adjustment was deemed necessary for SSRIs inhibiting CYP2D6.
population_specificity: 23 healthy participants
effective_dosage: 100 μg LSD (single dose), paroxetine (10 mg for 7 days, then 20 mg for 35 days)
interactions: Paroxetine (a CYP2D6 inhibitor) increased LSD's concentration; no significant interactions with autonomic effects or QTc interval.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the long-term safety and efficacy of LSD-assisted therapy in patients with anxiety, with or without life-threatening illness.
results_summary: Participants reported sustained reductions in anxiety and depression symptoms, with significant improvements in STAI-G and BDI scores, as well as positive changes in personality traits (decreased neuroticism, increased extraversion). The effects were attributed to the psychedelic experience.
population_specificity: Patients with anxiety, with or without life-threatening illness (n = 39).
effective_dosage: 200 μg LSD per session, administered orally.
study_duration: Follow-up assessments were conducted up to 94 weeks after the last LSD treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the effects of low doses of LSD on arousal, attention, and memory depend on an individual's baseline cognitive state.
results_summary: LSD reduced resting state EEG delta, theta, and alpha power, enhanced pre-attentive processing acutely, and blunted visual long-term potentiation. Effects were strongest in individuals with low baseline arousal/attention or high baseline memory performance, with some effects persisting at follow-up.
population_specificity: Healthy participants (N=53)
effective_dosage: 15 mcg, repeated doses on 4 occasions over 2 weeks

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a case of seizures following LSD ingestion in a patient on lithium therapy, suggesting a potential interaction.
results_summary: The study found that a 15-year-old female with treatment-resistant depression experienced three generalized seizures after LSD use, which only occurred after starting lithium, indicating a possible increased seizure risk with this combination.
population_specificity: 15-year-old female with treatment-resistant depressive disorder and recent low-dose lithium therapy.
interactions: LSD and lithium (potential increased seizure risk)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the experiences and perceptions of individuals using LSD for the first time, focusing on their expectations, side effects, and harm-reduction behaviors.
results_summary: First-time LSD users generally reported positive experiences exceeding expectations, with rare adverse effects and minimal need for emergency medical treatment. While mild fear was common, it did not deter future use.
population_specificity: 3,340 respondents who initiated LSD use in the past 12 months, sourced from the 2018 Global Drug Survey.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the dose-dependent effects of LSD on brain activity and functional connectivity in awake, drug-naive rats using MRI.
results_summary: LSD caused a dose-dependent increase in negative blood oxygen level-dependent signal, indicating decreased brain activity in regions like the prefrontal cortex, thalamus, and hippocampus. It also enhanced functional connectivity between the thalamus and somatosensory cortex, as well as cerebellar nuclei and brainstem areas.
population_specificity: Fully awake, drug-naive female and male rats.
study_duration: 30-minute imaging session, with data collected approximately 45 minutes post-injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the electrophysiological spectral signatures (EEG/MEG) of LSD and other psychedelics in individuals with depression and healthy controls to understand their mechanisms of action.
results_summary: LSD was associated with increased theta power in persons with major depressive disorder (MDD) and decreased spectral power in the alpha, beta, and delta bands in both healthy controls and individuals with depression. These effects align with ketamine's spectral changes, suggesting shared neurobiological mechanisms.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers and individuals with major depressive disorder (MDD) or treatment-resistant depression (TRD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate LSD's therapeutic potential, safety profile, and efficacy in treating conditions like alcohol use disorder, anxiety, and depression.
results_summary: The study found that LSD showed promise in treating alcohol use disorder, anxiety, and depression, with durable relief in 77% of participants at 1 year post-treatment and remission in 50% of generalized anxiety disorder cases after a single dose. Adverse events were mostly mild and transient, with rare serious incidents.
population_specificity: Patients with alcohol use disorder, anxiety, depression, and life-threatening illnesses.
study_duration: Single-dose intervention with follow-up at 1 year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the modification of depressive symptoms using a regimen of LSD microdoses versus placebo in patients with major depressive disorder (MDD).
results_summary: The abstract describes the study protocol but does not report results, as it is a prospective trial. The study will evaluate LSD's safety, mechanism, and treatment efficacy compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Patients meeting DSM-5 criteria for major depressive disorder.
effective_dosage: Titratable from 4 to 20 μg, two doses per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the behavioral effects of acute and repeated LSD exposure in zebrafish, focusing on anxiety-like behavior, boldness, and locomotion.
results_summary: Acute LSD exposure reduced high mobility and velocity at various doses, while repeated exposure showed no significant differences in anxiety, boldness, or locomotion compared to controls, even after withdrawal.
population_specificity: Zebrafish (Danio rerio)
effective_dosage: 1.5 µg/L, 15 µg/L, 150 µg/L (acute and repeated exposure)
study_duration: Acute exposure and repeated 10-day exposure, with a 7-day withdrawal period

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the tolerability and feasibility of an 8-week LSD microdosing regimen in patients with major depressive disorder before a larger randomized controlled trial.
results_summary: The study found that LSD microdosing was relatively safe and well-tolerated in healthy volunteers, with excellent adherence and compliance observed. Antidepressant response was to be assessed via MADRS scores, but results were not yet reported.
population_specificity: Patients meeting DSM-5 criteria for major depressive disorder (n=20).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether psychedelics, including LSD, could improve olfactory impairment (anosmia and microsmia) based on anecdotal reports.
results_summary: The study reported one case where a woman with childhood anosmia experienced olfactory improvement after ingesting 100 µg of LSD, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for olfactory dysfunction. The abstract also discusses possible mechanisms like serotonergic effects and neuroplasticity.
population_specificity: Individuals with olfactory impairment (anosmia or microsmia), including one case with childhood anosmia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review preclinical and clinical literature on LSD's effects on anxiety-like behaviors and its potential as an anxiolytic treatment.
results_summary: Preclinical and clinical findings indicate LSD may acutely exacerbate anxiety but induces long-lasting anxiolytic effects. Two randomized controlled trials showed a good safety profile and persistent anxiety reduction when combined with psychotherapy.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers and patients with anxiety disorders (with and without life-threatening conditions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore historical examples of LSD's use as a correctional tool and how institutional contexts shaped its application in therapy.
results_summary: The study found that enthusiasm for LSD's potential led experienced therapists to use it on vulnerable populations in institutional settings, highlighting how broader societal frameworks influenced past psychedelic therapy practices.
population_specificity: Vulnerable populations in correctional facilities and other institutional settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how music, as part of the "setting," influences brain state dynamics after LSD intake.
results_summary: The study found that LSD and music interaction altered brain activity in task-positive states, with LSD affecting combined activity of DMN, SOM, and VIS networks. Music alone showed potential long-term effects on resting-state activity involving task-positive networks.
population_specificity: 15 participants undergoing fMRI scanning under LSD and placebo conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of LSD therapy as a treatment for alcoholism in a controlled trial setting.
results_summary: The study found that LSD was not effective in treating alcoholism, but critics argued the methodology was flawed and anti-therapeutic, potentially skewing results. The Toronto group used a unique approach involving high doses and minimal therapeutic support, which some likened to torture.
population_specificity: Alcoholism patients
effective_dosage: Unusually large dose (specific amount not stated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify novel LSD-1 inhibitors using computational drug design methods to target cancer therapy.
results_summary: The study identified three nanomolar LSD-1 inhibitors of novel chemotypes through pharmacophore modeling and machine learning, demonstrating efficacy in inhibiting LSD-1 in neuroblastoma, pancreatic carcinoma, and glioblastoma cell lines.
population_specificity: In vitro cell lines (SH-SY5Y, Panc-1, U-87 MG) and enzymatic assays.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how LSD affects probabilistic reversal learning (PRL) in healthy humans, focusing on learning rates, reinforcement sensitivity, and exploration behavior.
results_summary: LSD increased reward and punishment learning rates, reduced stimulus stickiness (indicating heightened exploration), and influenced reinforcement sensitivity differently across task phases, suggesting enhanced behavioral plasticity.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether LSD affects the brain endocannabinoid system (eCBome), gut microbiome, and sociability in mice.
results_summary: LSD increased social preference and novelty, altered hippocampal eCBome and kynurenine levels, and changed gut microbiota composition, including reduced alpha diversity and shifts in bacterial taxa abundance.
population_specificity: Adult C57BL/6N male mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ketanserin could reverse the effects of LSD when administered after LSD and assess its impact on subjective, autonomic, and pharmacokinetic outcomes.
results_summary: Ketanserin reversed LSD's acute effects, reducing subjective effects from 8.5 to 3.5 hours, mitigated visual/acoustic alterations and ego dissolution, and reduced adverse cardiovascular effects without altering LSD's pharmacokinetics.
population_specificity: 24 healthy participants
effective_dosage: 100 µg LSD orally, followed by 40 mg ketanserin orally 1 hour later
interactions: Ketanserin (5-HT2A antagonist) effectively reversed LSD's effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of low doses of LSD on reward processing in healthy adults.
results_summary: Low doses of LSD (13 μg and 26 μg) increased reward-related brain activity, as measured by enhanced amplitudes of reward-related ERP components (RewP, FB-P3, LPP), compared to placebo. These effects were not associated with most subjective measures of drug effects.
population_specificity: 18 healthy adults
effective_dosage: 13 μg and 26 μg LSD, single doses
study_duration: Single administration per session (three sessions total)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine racial and age differences in perceived risk of LSD use compared to heroin.
results_summary: The study found that 66.7% of respondents perceived LSD as a great risk if used once or twice, with White respondents and multiracial individuals reporting lower perceived risk than other racial groups. Perceived risk also increased with age.
population_specificity: 41,679 respondents from the 2019 National Survey of Drug Use and Health.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of hand massage on autonomic activity, anxiety, relaxation, and sense of affinity in healthy individuals before clinical application.
results_summary: Hand massage increased parasympathetic nerve activity, reduced heart rate, and decreased state anxiety scores. It also improved willingness to communicate and sense of affinity toward the massage performer in 70% of subjects.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of uterine massage as an initial treatment for postpartum hemorrhage caused by uterine atony.
results_summary: The study found that uterine massage, along with intravenous oxytocin, is an initial treatment for postpartum hemorrhage. If unsuccessful, other techniques like uterine packing or arterial embolization may be considered.
population_specificity: Postpartum women experiencing hemorrhage due to uterine atony.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of massage as a non-pharmacological intervention for managing labor pain.
results_summary: The study found that massage may improve labor pain management and satisfaction with pain relief, with few adverse effects, though evidence was limited to single trials. It was categorized under "What may work" due to some supportive but not conclusive evidence.
population_specificity: Women in labor.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of massage therapy and yoga on prenatal depression and neonatal outcomes against standard prenatal care.
results_summary: Massage therapy significantly reduced depression, anxiety, and pain while improving relationship scores compared to the control group. Neonatal outcomes (gestational age and birthweight) were better in the massage group than the control but similar to the yoga group.
population_specificity: Prenatally depressed women (n=84).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness and predictors of massage in treating patients with posterior shoulder tightness.
results_summary: Massage significantly improved internal rotation ROM compared to the control group, with 21 out of 29 patients showing functional improvement. Effectiveness was influenced by symptom duration, functional score, and posterior deltoid tightness.
population_specificity: 43 women and 17 men (mean age 54 years) with posterior shoulder tightness.
effective_dosage: 18 minutes per session (6 minutes per muscle), two times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of various bowel care methods, including anal massage, for managing bowel problems in spinal cord injury patients.
results_summary: The abstract mentions anal massage as one of the methods used for bowel care but does not provide specific efficacy data for it. Improved bowel function was noted with other interventions like neostigmine and sacral root stimulators.
population_specificity: Patients with spinal cord injuries experiencing bowel problems.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of aromatherapy massage using lavender oil on reducing colic symptoms in infants.
results_summary: The study found that aromatherapy massage with lavender oil significantly reduced crying time in infants with colic compared to the control group. The treatment was deemed effective in alleviating colic symptoms.
population_specificity: 40 infants aged 2-6 weeks with gestational age 38-42 weeks, normal development, and colic symptoms.
effective_dosage: Not specified (abdominal massage with lavender oil, frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of LI4 acupressure on labor pain, labor duration, and patient satisfaction during the first stage of labor.
results_summary: LI4 acupressure significantly reduced subjective labor pain scores immediately and up to 120 minutes after intervention, shortened active and second-stage labor durations, and increased maternal satisfaction with no adverse effects reported.
population_specificity: Women at the beginning of the active phase of labor (3-4 cm cervical dilation with regular uterine contractions).
effective_dosage: LI4 acupressure applied at the onset of the active phase for the duration of each uterine contraction over 20 minutes.
